title: Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season : scientists | iNFOnews
message:
Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season: scientistsScientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO — Amanda Dunfield, *MANDATORY CREDIT*Original Publication Date July 31, 2024 - 1:01 AMHALIFAX - Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
"You can see it in the atmosphere, moving from Africa westward across the Atlantic," says Chris Fogarty, manager of the Canadian Hurricane Centre in Dartmouth, N.S.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.
event_breakdown: The Canadian Hurricane Centre says Hurricane Season Prediction issued in late May still holds true.

title: Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season : scientists – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
HALIFAX – Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year’s Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
Scientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
Only three named storms have formed over the Atlantic since hurricane season started on June 1 — tropical storms Alberto and Chris, and hurricane Beryl, which on July 2 became the earliest Category 5 hurricane to be recorded over the Atlantic.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
“Let’s not wait until these storms are in the news.”In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

title: Vermont man evacuates neighbors during flooding , weeks after witnessing a driver get swept away
message:
LYNDON, Vt. (AP) — Weeks after Jason Pilbin witnessed a driver get swept away by floodwaters, his northeastern Vermont community was ravaged again by flooding from heavy rains.
Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More heavy rains were in the forecast for the state on Wednesday with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.
event_breakdown: Lyndon, Vermont.

title: This Is Considered the Worst July Storm in Kentucky History
message:
As I await the return of the electricity, I thought I'd do a little digging into the history of July storms in Kentucky.
The Weather Channel's data indicates the '22 flood in Eastern Kentucky was the nation's deadliest non-tropical flash flood in 45 years.
The Worst July Storm in Kentucky's HistoryBut it was back in 1939 when Kentucky incurred the wrath of what would come to be classified by the National Weather Service as the worst July storm in the Commonwealth's history.
Additionally, the rapidly rising waters destroyed the Kentucky Mountain Bible Institute which was rebuilt as the Kentucky Mountain Bible College.

event_breakdown:
hurricanes
As the sun rises over Matlacha, Fla., the building lists, its first floor now a murky aquarium. The top of the building retains its familiar shape.

“I rather see it as a whole new canvass and just painting on it,” said Mac. “Just to make it beautiful. Just to make it the new Matlacha.”

Mac is an artist who moved to the area after Hurricane Charley ravaged parts of Fort Myers in 2004.

George Fazio is also an artist. He moved here from New York.

“I’m a painter so I guess it makes sense. Painters, you know, will make something out of anything. Any disaster we make art out of,” said Fazio.

George and Mac have become best friends, so it feels wrong to ask what they see when they look out onto Matlacha’s street.

“The building I see is not the issue,” Fazio said. “I at heart just want to see people with their families and their homes, and what’s missing is that part of it. I think that’s what’s heartbreaking.”

George, Mac and every other person who lives, works or owns property in this little island town off the Southwest coast of Florida’s biggest dilemmas is whether to put the building on stilts, rebuild or just leave the lot and move on.

None of them want to move away from Matlacha, but until the first floor is raised or demolished they are just here.

Other property owners aren’t waiting around.

title: Political Spin : Irresponsible forest management spawns catastrophic fires
message:
A column by Bruce UzelmanJasper, Alberta is the latest community to experience catastrophic wildfire.
Forest management policies, beginning in the early 1900s, prioritized fire suppression to preserve valuable timber and reforestation with the most commercially valuable species, which were coniferous, particularly pine.
The disastrous fire at Jasper demonstrates the impact of past and present forest management.
B.C.’s Forest Practices Board recommends “landscape forest management,” to provide protection against aggressive wildfire.
Rather, without extensive reform, Jasper is the first of many catastrophic wildfires that will befall Canada’s west in 2024 and beyond.

Fogarty said now is the time for people in Eastern Canada to prepare for strong winds, heavy rain and storm surges.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

title: How stormwater can impact our waterways
message:
LEXINGTON, Ky. (WKYT)—In 2006, the EPA and the Commonwealth sued the City of Lexington, saying that the city failed to properly manage stormwater.
After a system overhaul and some hard work, Lexington won a national award for stormwater mitigation and management in 2018.
When we get rain here in Kentucky, we get stormwater, excess water runoff that doesn’t soak into the ground after a storm.
However, during periods of excessive rainfall, new concerns can arise about stormwater mitigation efforts.
Unlike our sanitary sewer system, stormwater runoff is not treated but discharged directly into our creeks and streams, along with the pollutants it grabbed along the way.

2. Hurricane Laura - On August 27th, 2020, Hurricane Laura made landfall as a Category 4 storm near Cameron, Louisiana, causing significant damage to homes and businesses. The storm also caused widespread power outages and flooding.
3. Hurricane Sally - On September 14th, 2020, Hurricane Sally made landfall near Gulf Shores, Alabama, as a Category 2 storm. The storm caused significant damage to homes and businesses, as well as widespread power outages and flooding.
4. Tropical Storm Beta - On October 4th, 2020, Tropical Storm Beta made landfall near Port O'Connor, Texas, as a weak Category 1 storm. The storm caused minor damage but heavy rainfall, leading to flooding in parts of the southeastern United States.

title: Winston - Salem remains in severe drought , despite rain
message:
As drought persists across the state, Winston-Salem is experiencing its second-driest start to summer in the past 26 years.
The U.S. Drought Monitor’s weekly update last week showed Greensboro has improved from a severe drought to a moderate drought classification due to recent heavy and widespread rainfall.
Winston-Salem remains in severe drought marking the city’s third consecutive week in the severe drought designation.
Greensboro has had 6.79 inches of rain, just 0.63 inches below average, which explains the uneven recovery from drought conditions in the region.
This persistent dryness and the early onset of drought conditions are part of a broader pattern influenced by climate change.
event_breakdown: Winston Salem experiencing severe drought and Greensboro is improving towards a moderate drought with less rain than usual.

title: Storm Brewing Off Florida Coast Could Become Tropical Depression
message:
If it strengthens, it will be the second storm to affect the United States this season, following Hurricane Beryl, which struck Texas in early July.
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) is watching “a large tropical wave” that is set to enter the Caribbean on July 31, approaching the Lesser Antilles.
To become a tropical depression, this tropical wave would have to develop into a cyclone with “organized deep convection” and surface winds moving counter-clockwise around a “well-defined center,” producing maximum sustained winds of 38 mph or less, according to the NWS.
If the system takes shape, it will be introduced as Tropical Depression Debby.
Hurricane season began on June 1 and will run through Nov. 30.
event_breakdown: The target event is a large tropical wave that is set to enter the Caribbean on July 31. The National Hurricane Center is monitoring the wave, and if it develops, it will be introduced as Tropical Depression Debby.

title: Why renters suffer after hurricanes , floods and wildfires : NPR
message:
You may be more vulnerable to climate-driven disasterstoggle caption Ryan Kellman/NPRVenus James loved living in Matlacha, Florida.
toggle caption Ryan Kellman/NPRAs a result, in the immediate aftermath of a disaster, renters often face huge bills, starting with rent itself.
toggle caption Ryan Kellman/NPRMeanwhile, the cost of temporary housing also increases in places where many homes have been destroyed.
toggle caption Ryan Kellman/NPR“The people who were hit the hardest were the poorest,” says Char Seuffert, a longtime real estate agent on the island.
“Disaster creates disaster,” James says.
event_breakdown:
Matlacha, Florida
Venus James loved living in Matlacha, Florida.
Sadly, as disaster after disaster rained down, she paid the price. Financially, that is.
Renters like James had less money to spend on rent as their paychecks dwindled.
But they still have bills to pay. And in Florida, homeowners who didn’t have homeowners insurance could count on their tenant’s insurance to pay for damages. That’s expensive.
On average, people who had home insurance paid $64 less on their rent in the first year after a disaster than those who didn’t. In the end, the more money they had lost to disaster, the more it cost them.
“The people who were hit the hardest were the poorest,” says Char Seuffert, a real estate agent with deep roots in the area.
In the aftermath of disaster, renters can be the ones footing the bill for a lot of things they’d otherwise have insurance to cover. And that means they’re likely going to be paying out of pocket for repairs to their homes.
But there’s little help available to fix this. And that means these renters are that much more likely to default on their rent.
“Disaster creates disaster,” James says.

title: Vermont man evacuates neighbors during flooding , weeks after seeing driver get swept away
message:

Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More rain was forecast for central and northern Vermont on Wednesday, with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

And the strong winds that carry the layer along causes wind shear, which can tear storms apart.

title: CenterPoint wants $1 billion - plus Hurricane Beryl recovery costs to be covered by Houston - area customers – Houston Public Media
message:
CenterPoint EnergyIt took a matter of hours, maybe even minutes, for Hurricane Beryl to knock out electricity for more than 2.2 million customers in the Houston region.
CenterPoint CEO Jason Wells acknowledged during a special Texas Senate committee hearing Monday that the utility company plans to pass its recovery costs onto its 2.8 million customers in the Houston area.
State Sen. Carol Alvarado, a Houston Democrat, asked Wells whether CenterPoint would ask for a rate increase to recoup its storm recovery costs.
CenterPoint intends to increase their rates to recoup the cost of recovering from Hurricane Beryl, passing the cost on to the customer.
Texas also needs a better system for allowing utility companies to recoup their infrastructure and storm recovery costs, that do not correlate to increased costs for customers, according to Haverlah.
event_breakdown:
Hurricane Beryl - Hurricane Beryl knocked out electricity for more than 2.2 million customers in the Houston region. CenterPoint Energy plans to pass its recovery costs onto its 2.8 million customers in the Houston area.
Texas winter storm - Texas is still trying to recover from a winter storm that knocked out power for millions of customers. Some customers were without power for days, and some people even died due to the freezing temperatures.
Hurricane Harvey - Hurricane Harvey hit Texas in 2017, and caused major flooding in the Houston area. The hurricane caused billions of dollars in damage, and it took years for the region to recover.

title: Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and cause widespread power outages
message:
Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and cause widespread power outagesCANTON, Ga. (AP) — A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.
Repeated heavy rains and thunderstorms also have struck parts of the Southeast over the last week.
event_breakdown: Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and cause widespread power outages.

message:

Tenants at a St. James Town apartment building will not be given a rent break even though they were without full access to electricity and hot water for days in the aftermath of a storm that drenched Toronto.
According to Roth, the highrise building sustained "catastrophic" damage to its electrical system due to flooding that occurred during the July 16 storm.
Power was out in the building for days and power restoration still isn't fully complete.
Roth said the company urges tenants to use renters' insurance if they have it.

title: West Haven rolls out hurricane readiness plan ahead of active storm season
message:
The City of West Haven is preparing for an active hurricane and tropical storm season.
The city’s Emergency Management Director Rick Fontana held a meeting on Wednesday with city department heads to discuss their hurricane preparedness plan.
Despite hurricane season typically beginning from June through November, in West Haven, the hurricanes more often begin from August through September.
This year will be the first year the City of West Haven has the option for mandatory evacuations.
In addition, West Haven is also improving existing infrastructure in some flood-prone areas, including the installation of gates at the underpass on Campbell Avenue.

title: Why does Vermont keep flooding ? It complicated , but experts warn it could become the norm
message:
Vermont is flooding.
(AP Photo/Charles Krupa)Climate change warming the atmosphereExtreme flooding conditions like these are often the result of random, short-term natural weather patterns heightened by long-term, human-caused climate change.
With climate change, storms are forming in a warmer atmosphere, making extreme rainfall a more frequent reality.
A study last year in the journal Climate Change found that extreme precipitation in the Northeast will increase 52% by the end of the century.
A crumbling dam systemDams in Vermont are increasingly at risk as climate change brings heavier rains and more powerful storms.

message:

title: 2 years after Hurricane Ian , FEMA approves $2 million for Okeechobee County
message:
OKEECHOBEE COUNTY, Fla. — Nearly two years after a monster Hurricane Ian left a trail of damage in Okeechobee County, the federal government has approved a $2 million grant to reimburse the county for debris removal.
Ian, which at one point grew to Category 5 strength, hammered Florida in late September of 2022, downing trees, damaging roofs, and knocking out power to Okeechobee County residents.
"Approximately 180,868 cubic yards of vegetative debris and 4,796 cubic yards of hurricane-generated debris were removed from roads and public property," FEMA said.
WPTV Multiple mobile homes in Okeechobee County were damaged by Hurricane Ian's wrath.
Whitehead said the county is responsible to pay for the hurricane expenses as they're happening, and used money from an emergency fund, that will be replenished with the FEMA reimbursement.
event_breakdown: Event: Almost two years after a monster Hurricane Ian left a trail of damage in Okeechobee County, the federal government has approved a $2 million grant to reimburse the county for debris removal.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA
message:
Tokyo, July 31 : An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicentre was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east, Xinhua news agency reported.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

Location: Tokyo

title: Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific , forecasters say – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
MIAMI (AP) — Tropical Storm Carlotta has formed in the eastern Pacific, but is moving away from Mexico, forecasters said Wednesday.
The National Hurricane Center in Miami says in an advisory that a tropical depression was upgraded to the tropical storm, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 kph).
The system is centered about 310 miles (500 kilometers) southwest of Manzanilla, Mexico, and is moving northwest at 12 mph (19 kph).
Carlotta is forecast to become a hurricane on Friday.
However, no coastal watches or warnings were in effect with the storm.

title: Political Spin : Irresponsible forest management spawns catastrophic fires
message:
A column by Bruce UzelmanJasper, Alberta is the latest community to experience catastrophic wildfire.
Forest management policies, beginning in the early 1900s, prioritized fire suppression to preserve valuable timber and reforestation with the most commercially valuable species, which were coniferous, particularly pine.
The disastrous fire at Jasper demonstrates the impact of past and present forest management.
B.C.’s Forest Practices Board recommends “landscape forest management,” to provide protection against aggressive wildfire.
Rather, without extensive reform, Jasper is the first of many catastrophic wildfires that will befall Canada’s west in 2024 and beyond.

title: Heavy rain , flash flooding makes this July one of the wettest on record
message:
Heavy rain on Tuesday, July 30 that led to flash flooding in parts of Henderson County helped make this one of the wettest Julys on record at the Asheville Regional Airport.
As of Wednesday afternoon, this July ranks as the fifth wettest on record with 10.03 inches of rain.
Much of the rain came during the later part of July, with a daily record of 2.38 inches falling on Monday, July 22.
Monday night's rain brought over five inches to Laurel Park and more than two inches to parts of Etowah, Hendersonville and Flat Rock.
There is a low chance of flash flooding tonight, but anywhere that had heavy rain last night has a better chance of flooding if there is more rain tonight.

title: Could tropical wave in the Atlantic impact the Gulf Coast ?
message:
NEW ORLEANS (WVUE) - A tropical wave near the Lesser Antilles has the potential to affect the Gulf Coast.
As the tropical wave moves west through the Caribbean, it faces dry air, Saharan dust, wind shear, and interaction with Caribbean islands.
Tropical wave could develop as it nears south Florida (WVUE)Uncertainty remains about the system’s future.
If the wave avoids Caribbean islands and becomes organized, it could curve north earlier.
A weaker wave crossing the islands might miss the northern trough, feel the high-pressure ridge’s influence, and move further west into the Gulf.

message:

Doug Burgum declared a summer storm disaster for the central part of the state due to severe storms and flooding in the region from June 7 to July 17 in an executive order Wednesday.
In a news release, the governor’s office said the National Weather Service reported 6 to 9 inches of rainfall across central North Dakota during the more than five-week period.
The disaster declaration will remain in effect until Aug. 31, according to the executive order.
